title: Part 1: The Transmission
text:
Message from Command



Thank you for contributing your expertise to the cause of first contact!
We have received an encrypted transmission from the aliens, and the following output. It takes the form of statistical information, apparently about factors influencing productivity. We suspect the aliens may have an entirely coffee-based society!
Our diplomatic experts believe this is some kind of test. To establish communication, we need you to solve these questions to send the right message on the right channel.
Humanity’s future rests in your hands! Good luck.

title: Part 1: The Transmission
text:
Output


Model 1: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee, data = lm_df)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)       coffee  
  69.338824     0.009624

title: Part 1: The Transmission
text:
Response

Transmission Frequency
First, to determine the transmission frequency to use to send the response to the aliens, answer the following questions:

For every unit increase in coffee consumed, what is the increase in predicted productivity? What can you conclude about the relationship between coffee and productivity based on this information?
What is the equation of the line for this model?
What productivity score does the model predict for someone that consumes 8 cups of coffee a day? Make sure you use bs rounded to 2 decimal places, and round your answer as well.

The transmission frequency is the answer to question (3).


Code
Match up the equation of the line to the corresponding scatterplots below. The code to send will take the form of a four-letter code of the matched-up scatterplots in order from 1 to 4.









_____ 1. yi = 20.97 + -1.73xi + ei
_____ 2. yi = 16.69 + 0.24xi + ei
_____ 3. yi = 3.34 + 1.94xi + ei
_____ 4. yi = 9.89 + 1.02xi + ei

title: Part 1: The Transmission
text:
Transmission
To respond to the alien transmission, enter the following:
Transmission Frequency:  Hz  Code to Send:   Send Transmission!

title: Part 2: The Ship
text:
Message from Command



Great work, team! We’ve established contact thanks to your efforts.
The situation is more dire than we expected. It seems an alien ship crash-landed on Earth recently, with crucial information aboard. From what we can gather, the aliens are trying to improve their coffee-based society, and the ship contained highly sensitive research on this topic that they want to recover. But why was that information sent away in the first place…?
We’ve collected a map of all of the locations of recent reported UFO sightings. The aliens have also provided us with the last known location of their ship, but it’s been encrypted in yet more linear models! We are asking you again for your help to find the ship and help our new extraterrestrial allies.

title: Part 2: The Ship
text:
Output


Model 1: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee, data = lm_df)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-23.3091  -4.6321  -0.0388   5.1361  22.6869 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 69.338824   0.863736  80.278   <2e-16 ***
coffee       0.009624   0.168431   0.057    0.954    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 7.352 on 1930 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  1.692e-06, Adjusted R-squared:  -0.0005164 
F-statistic: 0.003265 on 1 and 1930 DF,  p-value: 0.9544




Model 2: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption and wellbeing



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing, data = lm_df)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-13.787  -3.302   0.109   3.419  13.714 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 65.76981    0.57164 115.054  < 2e-16 ***
coffee      -0.88148    0.11202  -7.869  5.9e-15 ***
wellbeing    2.68643    0.05324  50.456  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 4.829 on 1929 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.5689,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.5685 
F-statistic:  1273 on 2 and 1929 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Part 2: The Ship
text:
Tasks
Use the output above to answer the following questions.

How much variance in the outcome does each model explain? How much more variance does the second model explain compared to the first? Give your answers as percentages.
Assuming the sampling distribution of b is normal, calculate the confidence intervals for the bs in the second model. How can you interpret these CIs?
Which of these two models, if any, is a significant improvement over the null model? How do you know?

Once you have the answers, use them to find the latitude and longitude of the crashed ship and enter them in the map below. Make sure you round your answers to two decimal places!

title: Part 2: The Ship
text:
Find the Ship

Latitude

The first number is the answer to task 3.
The second number is the second digit of the upper bound from the coffee predictor from task 2.



Longitude

The first number is the third digit of the difference in R2 between the two models from task 1.
The third number is the second digit of the lower bound from the wellbeing predictor from task 2.

When you have found the ship, click on the marker to proceed.

title: Part 3
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 3
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 3
text:
Output


Model 3: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption, wellbeing, and AI use



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing + use_ai, data = lm_df)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-3.5375 -0.6661 -0.0033  0.6941  3.6734 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error  t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 99.78646    0.20667  482.830   <2e-16 ***
coffee       0.04617    0.02413    1.913   0.0559 .  
wellbeing    3.01252    0.01138  264.818   <2e-16 ***
use_ai      -4.95959    0.02444 -202.951   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.021 on 1928 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.9807,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9807 
F-statistic: 3.27e+04 on 3 and 1928 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16






Model 2 vs Model 3 comparison


Analysis of Variance Table

Model 1: productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing
Model 2: productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing + use_ai
  Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq     F    Pr(>F)    
1   1929 44976                                 
2   1928  2011  1     42965 41189 < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1






 Standardised Bs


Parameter   | Coefficient |       SE |         95% CI |  t(1928) |      p
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
(Intercept) |    5.11e-16 | 3.16e-03 | [-0.01,  0.01] | 1.62e-13 | > .999
coffee      |    6.24e-03 | 3.26e-03 | [ 0.00,  0.01] |     1.91 | 0.056 
wellbeing   |        0.86 | 3.23e-03 | [ 0.85,  0.86] |   264.82 | < .001
use ai      |       -0.66 | 3.27e-03 | [-0.67, -0.66] |  -202.95 | < .001

title: Part 3
text:
Tasks
Use the output above to answer the following questions.

Which is the better model, the second or third? In other words, is the third model (with three predictors) a significant improvement over the second model (with two predictors)?
Which predictor(s) in the better model are significant and which ones aren’t?
Which predictor in the better model has the biggest impact on the outcome?







Note



Make sure to take note of your answers! You will need them for the Kahoot! at the end of this section.

title: About
text:
About this site


[1] 2

title: Welcome!
text:
Welcome to the Analysing Data revision website! This site provides the materials for our revision sessions to help you prepare for the Analysing Data exam.
There are three different sessions in the revision session. They all cover the same content, just in different ways. Your session lead will tell you which of the options you have been allocated to. Select the correct option using the buttons below, or the navigation bar above.




Option 1 Option 2 Option 3

title: Part 3: The Vault
text:
Message from Command



Good and bad news, team. The good news is that we found the crash site thanks to your help. Inside, we recovered a large, securely locked vault. Our new alien friends were very excited by this progress, but quickly became agitated.
We finally managed to get them to tell us the problem, and that’s the bad news: productivity on their planet is being enforced by an out-of-control AI that is determined to prevent them improving their society any further. The vault contains access keys to the AI mainframe, which were sent to our planet to hide them away.
Which brings me to the worse news. The aliens tell us the AI has detected the signal from the access keys and has launched an invasion force to recover them. The first drones are only minutes away from entering our atmosphere! We have to ask you for your help once again: we must open the vault and retrieve the keys before the AI arrives, so we can deactivate it once and for all.
Humanity’s continued existence rests in your hands! Good luck.

title: Part 3: The Vault
text:
Output
Documentation retrieved from the crash site, believed to contain coded clues to the vault combination.
Predictor 1: coffee
Predictor 2: wellbeing
Predictor 3: use_ai

title: Part 3: The Vault
text:
Vault Lock
The vault lock combination consists of three numbers:

The first is the number of the better model (2 or 3).
The second is the number of the predictor that is NOT significant.
The third is the number of the predictor that has the biggest impact on the outcome.

When you have the combination, put it into the vault lock to retrieve the keys!
